docs.lead_paragraph: A House hearing on an Obama administration policy requiring insurers to pay for birth control for religious institutions’ employees was a scene of politics and soul-searching.

headline.seo: Birth Control Coverage Rule Debated at House Hearing
headline.main: Passions Flare as House Debates Birth Control Rule
headline.print_headline: Passions Flare as House Debates Birth Control Rule

docs.abstract: President Obama’s compromise plan to require free insurance coverage for contraceptives for women has touched off a tumultuous debate in which members of Congress mix political theater with soul-searching over potential threats to religious liberty.
docs.snippet: A House hearing on an Obama administration policy requiring insurers to pay for birth control for religious institutions’ employees was a scene of politics and soul-searching.

keywords.name: organizations

headline.main: Can We Have a Civil Debate Over Home Births?

docs.abstract: Several excellent writers have been trying to bring some light to the often heated discussion over where women give birth.
docs.snippet: Several excellent writers have been trying to bring some light to the often heated discussion over where women give birth.

docs.abstract: Political news from today's Times, plus a look at what's happening in Washington.
docs.snippet: Political news from today's Times, plus a look at what's happening in Washington.

headline.main: Insurance Answers, of a Sort, From Ankara

docs.abstract: American diplomats have been briefed --- sort of --- by Turkish officials about the new General Health Insurance law that requires U.S. citizens to sign up. "Unfortunately,'' said a message on the U.S. Embassy's Web site, envoys have "still not received adequate clarification from Turkish authorities on several key points of the law.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Supporters and opponents of President Obama’s health coverage requirement for all employers see it as a potent weapon for the November elections.

headline.seo: Both Sides Eager to Take Contraception Mandate Debate to Voters
headline.main: Both Sides Eager to Take Birth Control Coverage Issue to Voters
headline.print_headline: Both Sides Eager to Take Birth Control Coverage Issue to Voters

docs.abstract: Furor over Pres Obama’s birth control mandate has become entrenched, with supporters and opponents alike calling the subject a potent weapon for the 2012 elections; religious conservatives and Republicans have dismissed Pres Obama's effort to soften the rule, refusing to relinquish an issue that allows them to portray Obama as a threat to religious liberty and traditional values; some liberal groups feel the issue will play in favor of Democrats, mobilizing the powerful womens' vote.
docs.snippet: Supporters and opponents of President Obama’s health coverage requirement for all employers see it as a potent weapon for the November elections.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: For representatives in both parties who are seeking Senate seats, House membership has become a liability.

headline.seo: House Members Face Tough Senate Races
headline.main: Members of the House Face Uphill Battles for Senate
headline.print_headline: Members of Unpopular Club Face Uphill Battles for Senate

docs.abstract: Former members of the House of Representatives seeking Senate seats in the 2012 election are finding that their history in that deeply unpopular body is a political liability; several races that were initially considered a shoe-in for former Representatives have become contentious, as voters express their frustration with political deadlock in the House; phenomenon could be particularly bad for Republicans hoping to take the four seats necessary to gain control of the Senate.
docs.snippet: For representatives in both parties who are seeking Senate seats, House membership has become a liability.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders are putting the finishing touches on an agreement to extend the payroll tax cut and federal jobless benefits through 2012. The deal is imperfect but sound.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends last-minute Congressional plan to extend the payroll tax cut and federal jobless benefits is imperfect, but sound; calls extension a victory for Pres Obama and Democrats, who made it a centerpiece of their agenda, and who were able to force Republican compliance under mounting political pressure.
docs.snippet: Congressional leaders are putting the finishing touches on an agreement to extend the payroll tax cut and federal jobless benefits through 2012. The deal is imperfect but sound.

docs.lead_paragraph: The consultants’ job was to manage doctors for the newly created Physician Affiliate Group of New York. One of the consultants, Dr. Marc A. Bard, resigned this week.

headline.seo: New York’s New Hospitals Management Arm Loses Top Official
headline.main: City Agreed to Pay $1.95 Million for 2 Hospital Consultants
headline.print_headline: City Agreed to Pay $1.95 Million for 2 Hospital Consultants

docs.abstract: Documents show that New York City's Health and Hospitals Corp agreed to pay consulting company Navigant nearly $2 million a year for the services of Dr Marc A Bard and Martin Rosenberg in managing the Physician Affiliate Group of New York; Bard has resigned for unknown reasons, but some doctors had privately complained about the high level of compensation being drawn from a financially strained system serving the city's poor; it is not clear if Rosenberg is still consulting for the city's hospital system.
docs.snippet: The consultants’ job was to manage doctors for the newly created Physician Affiliate Group of New York. One of the consultants, Dr. Marc A. Bard, resigned this week.

keywords.value: Physician Affiliate Group of New York
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s plan to require insurers to cover the costs of birth control is being complicated by the fact that many religiously affiliated organizations insure themselves.

headline.seo: Self-Insurance Complicates Deal on Birth Control

docs.abstract: Obama administration’s plan to require insurers to cover the costs of birth control is being complicated by the fact that many religiously affiliated organizations insure themselves; administration has remained mostly silent on how they will be treated, other than to say that the details will be worked out in meetings with religious leaders.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration’s plan to require insurers to cover the costs of birth control is being complicated by the fact that many religiously affiliated organizations insure themselves.

byline.contributor: Reed Abelson and Laurie Goodstein contributed reporting.
